facts.text: The appellant, Gherulal Parakh, and the first respondent, Mahadeodas Maiya, managers of two joint families entered into a partnership to carry on wagering contracts with two firms of Hapur, namely, Messrs. Mulchand Gulzarimull and Baldeosahay Surajmull.

It was agreed between the partners that the said contracts would be made in the name of the respondents on behalf of the firm and that the profit and loss resulting from the transactions would be borne by them in equal shares.
In implementation of the said agreement, the first respondent entered into 32 contracts with Mulchand and 49 contracts with Baldeosahay and the net result of all these transactions was a loss.
The first respondent had to pay to the Hapur merchants the entire amount due to them.

As the appellant denied his liability to bear his share of the loss, the first respondent along with his sons filed O. S. No. 18 of 1937 in the Court of the Subordinate Judge, Darjeeling, for the recovery of half of the loss incurred in the transactions with Mulchand.
In the plaint of first suit, he reserved his right to claim any further amount in respect of transactions with Mulchand that might be found due after accounts were finally settled.
That suit was referred to arbitration and on the basis of the award, the Subordinate Judge made a decree in favour of the first respondent and his sons for a sum of Rs. 3,375.

After final accounts were settled between the first respondent and the two merchants of Hapur and amounts paid, the first respondent instituted a suit (Money Suit No. 5 of 1940) for recovery of Rs. 5,300 with interest.
Plaint was amended to claim relief on basis that the firm had been dissolved.

Appellant and his sons pleaded that agreement to enter into wagering contracts was unlawful under s. 23 of Contract Act, suit barred under s. 69 of Partnership Act as unregistered, and barred under O. 2 r. 2 CPC.

Subordinate Judge found agreement void as forbidden by law and opposed to public policy, claim not barred by O. 2 r. 2 CPC, no partnership between joint families so s. 69 inapplicable, dismissed suit.

High Court held partnership between two managers not joint families, valid; single venture for season, dissolved after; wagering void under s. 30 but not unlawful under s. 23; payments established Rs. 7,615 to Baldeosahay; decree for Rs. 3,807-8-0 without interest.

Parties jointly entered into contracts with two merchants between March 23, 1937, and June 17, 1937; complete accounts obtained after June 17, 1937; notice issued for Rs. 4,146-4-3 being half of total payments.
Suit filed for recovery of said amount; written statement June 12, 1940, no s.69 plea; additional WS Nov 9, 1941 with s.69; plaint amended to plead dissolution.
Partnership only in respect of forward contracts with two specified individuals for particular season; dissolved on completion per s.42 Partnership Act.
Courts found on evidence that partnership object was wagering transactions with no intention to give/take delivery but deal in differences.

legal_issues.text: Whether the partnership agreement to carry on wagering contracts is unlawful under s. 23 of the Indian Contract Act.
Whether the suit is barred by s. 69 of the Partnership Act.
Whether the claim is barred under O. 2 r. 2 CPC.
Whether the partnership was between joint families or managers.

petitioner_arguments.text: Agreement between parties to enter into wagering contracts unlawful under s. 23 Contract Act.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 23, Indian Contract Act; wagering void under s.30 hence forbidden by law

petitioner_arguments.text: Partnership not registered, suit barred under s.69 Partnership Act.
Suit barred under O.2 r.2 CPC as cause of action arose in prior suit.
High Court finding of dissolution not supported by pleadings or evidence.
Object opposed to public policy and immoral.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 23 Contract Act; Hindu texts; public policy

respondent_arguments.text: No finding that first respondent entered wagering transactions; no common intention for wager.
Partnership dissolved; suit for accounts of dissolved firm not barred by s.69(1)(2).
Wagering void under s.30 but not unlawful under s.23.

court_reasoning.text: Partnership for single season/ventures with specified merchants, dissolved on completion per s.42 Partnership Act; facts support High Court finding.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Pleadings and conduct imply limited duration.

court_reasoning.text: Concurrent finding that transactions were wagering contracts with no intention of delivery; accept as fact.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Partnership object to carry on wagering transactions.

court_reasoning.text: Wagering void under s.30 but not forbidden by law/illegal under s.23; void â‰  illegal; collateral contracts enforceable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Distinction between void and illegal contracts upheld in English/Indian precedents.

court_reasoning.text: No principle of public policy invalidates wagering contracts; common law enforced them; statutes made void not illegal.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Public policy not to be expanded; wagering tolerated.

court_reasoning.text: Immorality under s.23 limited to sexual immorality, not wagering.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No authority extends immorality to wagering.

court_reasoning.text: Claim not barred by O.2 r.2 as cause for remaining claim arose later.

holdings.text: Partnership to carry on wagering transactions is not unlawful under s.23 Contract Act though transactions void under s.30.
Partnership dissolved after season per s.42; s.69 not bar to suit for accounts.

precedents_cited.relevance: Broker entitled to indemnity despite wagering; void not illegal.
Gaming Act 1845 makes wagers void not illegal.
Agent can recover winnings under collateral contract.
Majority upheld substituted agreement; dissent on scope of s.18.
Partnership for betting valid; accounts lie.
Substituted agreement for wager unenforceable under Gaming Act 1845 s.18.
Wagers enforceable under common law in India.
Agent recovers betting loss from principal.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Bombay v. R.M.D. Chamarbaugwala
precedents_cited.relevance: Hindu texts condemn gambling but not legally enforced.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Contract Act, 1872
statutes_cited.relevance: Object unlawful if forbidden by law, immoral or opposed to public policy; wagers void but not unlawful.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Partnership Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Unregistered firm suit barred except for dissolved firm accounts; dissolution on completion of venture.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: No bar as cause of action for part claim arose later.

statutes_cited.name: Gaming Act, 1845 (UK)
statutes_cited.relevance: Wagers void and unenforceable; basis for s.30 Contract Act.

statutes_cited.name: Gaming Act, 1892 (UK)
statutes_cited.relevance: Collateral promises unenforceable; not adopted in India.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld High Court decree in favor of first respondent for Rs. 3,807-8-0 plus small item, without interest, as partnership not unlawful; appeal against Calcutta High Court judgment dismissed.
outcome.relief_granted: Decree for Rs. 3,807-8-0 to first respondent; suits of other plaintiffs/dismissed against other defendants.

key_quotes.text: "The consideration or object of an agreement is lawful, unless- it is forbidden by law, or the Court regards it as immoral, or opposed to public policy."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes s.23 Contract Act central to decision.

key_quotes.text: To constitute a wagering contract there must be proof that the contract was entered into upon terms that the performance of the contract should not be demanded, but only the difference in prices should be paid.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "What is void can be equated with what is forbidden by law?" This argument... has uniformly been rejected.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects equation of void wagering with illegal.

key_quotes.text: Public policy is a very unstable and dangerous foundation on which to build until made safe by decision.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Limits application of public policy doctrine.
